node.title: Grammys Remove Taylor Swift and Others From Olivia Rodrigo Nomination
node.alt: Olivia Rodrigo’s “Sour” is up for seven awards at the 2022 Grammys, including album of the year. But not all songwriters credited on the LP are eligible for the album honor.
node.description: Swift, Jack Antonoff and St. Vincent are credited on “Sour,” but the awards don’t count interpolations — rerecorded quotations from other songs — toward album of the year consideration.
node.content: ["In the latest tweak to this year\u2019s Grammy Award nominations, Taylor Swift and two of her collaborators have been removed from the ballot as songwriters on Olivia Rodrigo\u2019s \u201cSour,\u201d which is up for album of the year.", "Why? Months after the release of \u201cSour,\u201d Swift, Jack Antonoff and Annie Clark (better known as St. Vincent) were added to the credits of Rodrigo\u2019s song \u201cDeja Vu\u201d after similarities were pointed out between that track and Swift\u2019s \u201cCruel Summer,\u201d from 2019. But while the Grammys now recognize most songwriters for album of the year \u2014 which, in the case of releases by Kanye West and Justin Bieber, brings in dozens of names \u2014 it disqualifies the writers of samples or \u201cinterpolations,\u201d a term of art for snippets of music that are recreated in a studio rather than lifted from an earlier recording.", "When the official nominations were announced in November, Swift, Antonoff and Clark were on the ballot. But on Sunday, the Recording Academy, the organization behind the awards, removed them. (Swift remains an album of the year contender for her own release, \u201cEvermore.\u201d)", "\u201cLast week, we received the correct credits from the label that recognize Annie Clark, Jack Antonoff and Taylor Swift as songwriters of an interpolation on the track, \u2018Deja Vu,\u2019\u201d the academy said in a statement. \u201cIn keeping with current Grammy guidelines, as songwriters of an interpolated track, Clark, Antonoff and Swift are not nominees in the album of the year category for \u2018Sour.\u2019\u201d", "The ban on interpolation credits also means that the writers of another track, Paramore\u2019s \u201cMisery Business\u201d \u2014 who were added to the official credits for Rodrigo\u2019s song \u201cGood 4 U\u201d \u2014 cannot share in the nod for \u201cSour.\u201d Another \u201cSour\u201d track, \u201c1 Step Forward, 3 Steps Back,\u201d also interpolates a Swift song, \u201cNew Year\u2019s Day\u201d (2017), written by Swift and Antonoff.", "Grammy rules also explain the absence of a songwriting nomination for Cole Porter on Tony Bennett and Lady Gaga\u2019s \u201cLove for Sale,\u201d a collection of a classic Porter songs like \u201cNight and Day,\u201d \u201cIt\u2019s De-Lovely\u201d and the title track. The awards recognize only the contributors of new material; most of Porter\u2019s songs on the album are standards that date to the 1930s.", "Last week, the academy removed Marilyn Manson from the best rap song category and added a songwriter, Linda Chorney, to the best American roots song category. (Manson was cited in error as a writer on West\u2019s \u201cJail,\u201d and Chorney, who has criticized the Grammy process in the past, was reinstated after an \u201caudit\u201d by the academy\u2019s accounting firm flagged her name.)", "In last month\u2019s nominations, the academy also expanded the ballot for in the top four categories \u2014 album, record and song of the year, and best new artist \u2014 to 10 slots apiece, from eight, after a last-minute approval by the organizations\u2019s board of trustees.", "The 64th annual Grammy Awards ceremony will be held on Jan. 31."]
